Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Modern Secondary Ion Spectrometer for Multidisciplinary Research and Training of Next Generation Scientists
Award.AbstractNarration:
Clark Atlanta University (CAU) proposes to the National Science Foundation's MRI program to acquire a modern secondary ion mass spectrometer for multidisciplinary research and training of next generation scientists, i. e., undergraduate, graduate and post-doctoral students in physics, materials science, and chemistry. The new instrument will replace a single investigator, custom built system that is over 30 years old. The tool will significantly enhance the research infrastructure of CAU and it will provide a high level of research and training opportunities for local materials research community. This will augment a suite of existing characterization tools that are oriented to impact research lines in various areas of materials research. This multi-user tool will be configured to serve the multidisciplinary needs of a diverse faculty representing 6 STEM departments, 3 Historically Black College or Universities, and 2 Minority Serving Institutions.

This acquisition will provide depth profile, chemical species identification, stoichiometry, and expanded imaging analysis capability. This will augment a suite of existing characterization tools that are oriented to impact research lines in solid state lighting, polymer synthesis and functionalization, semiconductors, two-dimensional topological materials and device processing. The shared access of this tool will broadly impact and foster interdisciplinary collaborations across departments and institutions and provide a major training resource for the next generation of materials scientists. This community effort has already had a significant impact on the number of under-represented minorities and women in the STEM disciplines. The tool will enhance students with readily marketable skills in materials analysis and characterization to compete globally. This acquisition in conjunction with the existing instrumentation will establish a suite of state-of-the art materials characterization tools that are unique to the geographical area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Clark Atlanta University (CAU) acquired a modern secondary ion mass spectrometer (SIMS) for multidisciplinary research and training of next generation scientists, i. e., undergraduate, graduate and post-doctoral students in physics, materials science, and chemistry. The instrument is a state-of-the-art Hiden Analytical SIMS Plus Workstation. Its acquisition replaced an aging, custom built, ion pumped, ultrahigh vacuum SIMS system based on a differentially pumped oxygen ion gun with a quadrupole detection system driven by vacuum tube electronics. The tool significantly enhances the research infrastructure of CAU and allows us to provide a high level of research and training opportunities for our local materials research community. The intellectual merit of this acquisition is that the instrument provides depth profile, chemical species identification, stoichiometry, and imaging analysis. This acquisition augments a suite of existing characterization tools that are oriented to impact research lines in solid state lighting, polymer synthesis and functionalization, semiconductors, two-dimensional topological materials and device processing.

This multi-user tool is configured to serve the multidisciplinary needs of 7 diverse faculty members representing 6 STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) departments, 3 HBCUs (Historically Black College or University), and 2 MSIs (Minority Serving Institution). Three of the faculty are underrepresented minorities (URM) and includes one woman. The HBCU institutions are CAU, Morehouse College (MC) and Spelman College (SC) and are constituent members of the Atlanta University Center. The MSIs are Georgia State University (GSU) and Georgia Institute of Technology (GT). These institutions are broadly impacted by the shared access to major research instrumentation that fosters interdisciplinary collaborations across departments and institutions and provide a major training resource for the next generation of materials scientists. This community effort has made a significant impact on the number of URMs and women in the STEM disciplines. Most recently the HBCU faculty were part of a PREM award project associated with the GT MRSEC on graphene. The PI is also an adjunct professor with GSU and can advise/co-advise GSU PhD students. The tool enhances our students with readily marketable skills in materials analysis and characterization to compete globally.

This acquisition in conjunction with the existing instrumentation here at CAU establishes a suite of state-of-the art materials characterization tools that are unique to the geographical area. The University has established a core research facility to maximize the utilization of its instrumentation. This core research facility serves the educational and research needs of the undergraduate and graduate students, faculty and research staff of the science departments and collaborators in the immediate vicinity. Its establishment represents a commitment by the institution to provide for the maintenance of a quality state-of-the-art facility in materials analysis and characterization which will enhance the quality of instruction, provide for a more varied and intense research experience for students and better position the faculty to be competitive.
